title: Head from a Shabty of King Akhenaten
description:
Head of Akhenaten probably from an ushabti but possibly from a statuette. Royal uraeus on forehead. 
Condition: The lower part of the chin, the right side of the headdress and the neck and back of the headdress are missing. Nose and uraeus chipped.

museum_location.name: This item is not on view

labels.content: The four stone shabties made for King Akhenaten illustrate the royal ideal in the Eighteenth Dynasty. They are a representative sample of the materials used to create hundreds of shabties for this king. Each stone type symbolizes a divinity related to the afterlife. For example, the red shabty associates Akhenaten with Re, the sun god, while the black granite one links him to Osiris, represented as the fertile soil of Egypt.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: To Live Forever: Egyptian Treasures from the Brooklyn Museum
